docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 2 POWERS OF COURT TO GIVE DIRECTIONS [ss 61–63]

heading.title: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
DIVISION 2 POWERS OF COURT TO GIVE DIRECTIONS [ss 61–63]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 6 CASE MANAGEMENT AND INTERLOCUTORY MATTERS [ss 56–89]
DIVISION 2 POWERS OF COURT TO GIVE DIRECTIONS [ss 61–63]

leg:heading.title: POWERS OF COURT TO GIVE DIRECTIONS [ss 61–63]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 61] s 61 Directions as to practice and procedure generally (cf SCR Part 23, rule 4; Act No 9 1973, section 68A)

leg:heading.title: Directions as to practice and procedure generally (cf SCR Part 23, rule 4; Act No 9 1973, section 68A)

p.text: The court may, by order, give such directions as it thinks fit (whether or not inconsistent with rules of court) for the speedy determination of the real issues between the parties to the proceedings.
In particular, the court may, by order, do any one or more of the following:
it may direct any party to proceedings to take specified steps in relation to the proceedings,
it may direct the parties to proceedings as to the time within which specified steps in the proceedings must be completed,
it may give such other directions with respect to the conduct of proceedings as it considers appropriate.
If a party to whom such a direction has been given fails to comply with the direction, the court may, by order, do any one or more of the following:
it may dismiss the proceedings, whether generally, in relation to a particular cause of action or in relation to the whole or part of a particular claim,
it may strike out or limit any claim made by a plaintiff,
it may strike out any defence filed by a defendant, and give judgment accordingly,
it may strike out or amend any document filed by the party, either in whole or in part,
it may strike out, disallow or reject any evidence that the party has adduced or seeks to adduce,
it may direct the party to pay the whole or part of the costs of another party,
it may make such other order or give such other direction as it considers appropriate.

Subsection (3) does not limit any other power the court may have to take action of the kind referred to in that subsection or to take any other action that the court is empowered to take in relation to a failure to comply with a direction given by the court.
Legislation cited in [s 61.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 62.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 31, r 29.5, 29.6.

The statement of the court’s directions power in CPA s 61(2) is complemented by both the even more general statement in UCPR r 2.1, and also by the illustrative exegesis in UCPR r 2.3 In addition to these provisions, CPA sÂ 62 and UCPR r 29.5 confer particular powers to give directions directly related to the conduct of the hearing of proceedings. Additional rules relating to the conduct of hearings, which include power to direct the use of witness statements, and provisions governing the use of expert evidence, are contained in UCPR Pt 31 . Those powers, and the general provisions relating to the conduct of hearings, are dealt with in the notes to UCPR rrÂ 29.5 and 29.6 .

The discretionary powers conferred by CPA s 61(3), to sanction noncompliance with direction, have to be exercised in accordance with the obligations imposed by CPA ss 56–60. In particular, their exercise is subject to the mandatory obligation to have regard to the overriding purpose and the objectives of case management: Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750Â at [36]–[47] (defence struck out for default without proper regard to CPA ss 56 and 57); Rahman v Bimson [2010] NSWSC 338; BC201002471Â at [24] per McCallum J (potential dismissal of proceedings).

Dismissal of proceedings under the present section does not involve a determination on the merits. The dismissal does not preclude the commencement of fresh proceedings: Greywolf Resources NL vÂ Wilkinson [2011] NSWSC 1604; BC201110446Â (referring to CPA sÂ 61).
Legislation cited in [s 61.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 2.1.

CPA s 61(3) permits the court to impose various sanctions, including giving judgment to an opposing party, where a party fails to comply with directions. The power complements the sanction power implicit in the courts’ incidental power to control their procedures. The principles that govern, and the considerations relevant to, the exercise of the sanction power, are discussed in the notes to UCPR r 2.1 and especially [2.1.20] .

level.toc-caption: [s 61.15] Directions — “for” the determination and disposal of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 61.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ssÂ 56(2), 57(2), 58.

heading.title: Directions — “for” the determination and disposal of proceedings

p.text: The court’s powers to give directions “for the speedy determination of the real issues” (CPA s 61(1)) and “for the just, quick and cheap disposal of the proceedings” (UCPR rÂ 2.1) are similar but, arguably not precisely congruent: McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2010] NSWCA 104; BC201003694Â (unlike UCPR 2.1, directions under CPA s 61(1) are only permitted by their potential impact on the actual timeliness of the determination of disputed issues). Subject to that possible limitation, both powers have to be given a “liberal interpretation”, especially in light of CPA ssÂ 56(2) , 57(2) and 58 : McGuirk v University of New South Wales, above at [10], [11] and [142]. Depending on the particular circumstances, the powers under either CPA s 61(1) or UCPR rÂ 2.1 may permit directions relating to dealings between the parties concerning conduct that is not immediately related to the actual conduct of the proceedings. For example, the court may direct the parties:

to correspond only with their respective legal representatives: Jenolan Caves Pty Ltd vÂ Field [2007] NSWSC 1117; BC200708551Â (direction to restrain defendant from sending letters personally to directors and officers of the plaintiff);
to refrain from serving particular kinds of documents: McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2009] NSWSC 253; BC200902405Â (direction to restrain service of notices to admit); or

to restrict their communications to those required for the purpose of conducting the proceedings: McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2009] NSWSC 253; BC200902405Â (direction to restrain letters to opposing party’s officers and legal representatives) — but see McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2010] NSWCA 104; BC201003694Â at [159] (power not enlivened by CPA s 61(1) in the particular circumstances — UCPR r 2.1 power not relied on at first instance).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 62] s 62 Directions as to conduct of hearing (cf Act No 52 1970, section 87; Act No 9 1973, section 77(4); SCR Part 34, rules 6 and 6AA)

leg:heading.title: Directions as to conduct of hearing (cf Act No 52 1970, section 87; Act No 9 1973, section 77(4); SCR Part 34, rules 6 and 6AA)

p.text: The court may, by order, give directions as to the conduct of any hearing, including directions as to the order in which evidence is to be given and addresses made.
The court may, by order, give directions as to the order in which questions of fact are to be tried.
Without limiting subsections (1) and (2), the court may, by order, give any of the following directions at any time before or during a hearing:
a direction limiting the time that may be taken in the examination, cross-examination or re-examination of a witness,
a direction limiting the number of witnesses (including expert witnesses) that a party may call,
a direction limiting the number of documents that a party may tender in evidence,
a direction limiting the time that may be taken in making any oral submissions,
a direction that all or any part of any submissions be in writing,
a direction limiting the time that may be taken by a party in presenting his or her case,
a direction limiting the time that may be taken by the hearing.
A direction under this section must not detract from the principle that each party is entitled to a fair hearing, and must be given a reasonable opportunity:
to lead evidence, and
to make submissions, and
to present a case, and
at trial, other than a trial before the Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division, to cross-examine witnesses.
[subs (4) am Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
In deciding whether to make a direction under this section, the court may have regard to the following matters in addition to any other matters that the court considers relevant:
the subject-matter, and the complexity or simplicity, of the case,
the number of witnesses to be called,
the volume and character of the evidence to be led,
the need to place a reasonable limit on the time allowed for any hearing,
the efficient administration of the court lists,
the interests of parties to other proceedings before the court,
the costs that are likely to be incurred by the parties compared with the quantum of the subject-matter in dispute,
the court’s estimate of the length of the hearing.
At any time, the court may, by order, direct a solicitor or barrister for a party to give to the party a memorandum stating:
the estimated length of the trial, and the estimated costs and disbursements of the solicitor or barrister, and
the estimated costs that, if the party were unsuccessful at trial, would be payable by the party to any other party.
Legislation cited in [s 62.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 62(1) , s 62(5).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 PtÂ 31, rrÂ 2.1, 2.3, rÂ 29.5, 29.6, rrÂ 31.17, rÂ 31.4.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCRÂ Pt 34 r 6(1), SCRÂ Pt 34 r6AA.

The present section complements the several provisions of the CPA and UCPR designed to give courts ample power to give effect to the overriding purpose of the “just, quick and cheap resolution of proceedings”. The general directions power contained in sÂ 62(1) complements the directions power in UCPR rrÂ 2.1 and 2.3 and is in similar terms to the power conferred by UCPR rÂ 29.5 . That rule derives from the former SCRÂ Pt 34 r 6(1) . The permissible directions inclusively detailed in sÂ 62(3), the limiting consideration expressed in sÂ 62(2) and the relevant considerations set out in s 62(5) , substantially reproduce (but with some re-expression and additions) the provisions of the former SCRÂ Pt 34 r6AA . The notes to UCPR rrÂ 29.5 and 29.6 contain detailed notes relevant to the exercise of the directions power in relation to the conduct of hearings. Additional rules relating to the conduct of hearings, which include power to direct the use of witness statements ( rÂ 31.4 ), and provisions governing the use of expert evidence ( rrÂ 31.17 ff), are contained in UCPR PtÂ 31 .

level.toc-caption: [s 62.10] The requirement of a fair hearing and reasonable opportunity

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 62.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 62(3).

heading.title: The requirement of a fair hearing and reasonable opportunity

p.text: The permissible directions exemplified in sÂ 62(3) are typically expressed in terms of limiting, rather than excluding, the various activities to which they refer. This distinction, and the explicit wording of sÂ 62(3) , recognises the fundamental entitlement of the parties to a fair hearing and a reasonable opportunity to be heard: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141 at 145; 67 ALR 21; BC8601459Â (judge finding against party on a basis disavowed in the course of argument) Taylor v Taylor (1979) 143 CLR 1; 25 ALR 418; BC7900069Â (orders made in the absence of a party and on the basis of disputed evidence). That fundamental entitlement will ordinarily require parties to be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present and test evidence and to advance their submissions: Palmer Tube Mills (Aust) Pty Ltd v Semi [1998] 4 VR 439; BC9800618Â (cross examination ought not be the subject of a general exclusion). This ordinary requirement emphasises the nature and sufficiency of the opportunity afforded to a party to advance their case, and is conceptually distinct from the question whether the party has accurately understood, and taken appropriate advantage of, the opportunity: Sullivan vÂ St George Community Housing Ltd [2010] NSWCA 248; BC201007148 atÂ [57]Â (unrepresented litigant — inability to identify an “error of law” ground of appeal). The prohibition against detracting from providing parties with a reasonable opportunity necessarily assumes that loss, or undue restriction, of the opportunity could have affected the result by the presentation of admissible evidence or reliance on arguable points of fact or law: Stead v State Government Insurance Commission (1986) 161 CLR 141 at 145; 67 ALR 21; BC8601459Â . Consequently, the steps necessary to provide a “fair hearing” and “adequate opportunity” depend on the actual issues to be determined in the particular proceedings. In some proceedings, for example those involving applications for extension of time or leave to proceed, it may be appropriate to exclude particular cross examination if the relevant issue is the availability of apparently material evidence rather than its actual accuracy or ultimate reliability: Scanlon v American Cigarette Co (Overseas) Pty Ltd (No 1) [1987] VR 261Â .
Legislation cited in [s 62.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 56, sÂ 62(3), sÂ 62(4)(d).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 [29.5.45], [31.18A.5].

CPA sÂ 62(3) permits the court to limit the length of cross examination. In addition both the general requirement of relevance and the particular obligation imposed by CPA sÂ 56 will permit the court to dispense with cross examination in some circumstances. The relevance requirement may justify dispensing with cross examination where the particular evidence is, on proper analysis, not directly material to the issues required to be determined, or where, provided the evidence is apparently credible, it is not necessary to finally resolve the parties’ contentions in relation to it. Considerations of these kinds may apply, for example, in proceedings for leave to proceed or applications for extensions of time: Scanlon v American Cigarette Co (Overseas) Pty Ltd (NoÂ 1) [1987] VR 261Â (application for extension of time — no cross examination on medical evidence relevant only to substantive proceedings).

The particular obligations imposed by case management principles may also justify excluding cross examination in particular circumstances — such as applications for interlocutory relief: see the discussion in [25.1.55] and also [29.5.70] . However both CPA sÂ 62(4)(d) and general principle suggest the inherent undesirability of unduly restricting, or prohibiting, cross examination where the proceedings require the determination of a material and contentious issue: Palmer Tube Mills (Aust) Pty Ltd v Semi [1998] 4 VR 439 at 449; BC9800618Â (application for leave to proceed — jurisdiction contingent on proof of “serious injury” — cross examination and submissions wrongly precluded).

Inappropriate restrictions on a party’s ability to contest the proceedings will breach the rules of procedural fairness: Byrne v Law Institute of Victoria Pty Ltd [2005] VSC 509; BC200511659Â (investigation of a complaint made against a solicitor by Law Institute, complaint resolved on the papers). Between the two extremes of permissible and impermissible restrictions on the length and scope of cross examination there is the practical difficulty of properly resolving disputed questions of fact “on the papers” (ie, in the absence of appropriate cross examination): Humphries v Poljak [1992] 2 VR 129 at 133; (1991) 14 MVR 1Â (whether injury was “serious”); Petkovski v Galletti [1994] 1 VR 436 at 445; (1993) 68 LIJ 69bÂ : see also [29.5.45] and [31.18A.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 63] s 63 Directions with respect to procedural irregularities (cf Act NoÂ 52 1970, section 81; Act No 9 1973, section 159; Act No 11 1970, section 75A)

leg:heading.title: Directions with respect to procedural irregularities (cf Act NoÂ 52 1970, section 81; Act No 9 1973, section 159; Act No 11 1970, section 75A)

p.text: This section applies to proceedings in connection with which there is, by reason of anything done or omitted to be done, a failure to comply with any requirement of this Act or of rules of court, whether in respect of time, place, manner, form or content or in any other respect.
Such a failure:
is to be treated as an irregularity, and
subject to subsection (3), does not invalidate the proceedings, any step taken in the proceedings or any document, judgment or order in the proceedings.
The court may do either or both of the following in respect of proceedings the subject of a failure referred to in subsection (1):
it may, by order, set aside the proceedings, any step taken in the proceedings or any document, judgment or order in the proceedings, either wholly or in part,
it may exercise its powers to allow amendments and to make orders dealing with the proceedings generally.

The court may not take action of the kind referred to in subsection (3)(a) on the application of any party unless the application is made within a reasonable time and, in any case, before the party takes any fresh step in the proceedings after becoming aware of the failure.

level.toc-caption: [s 63.2] Any requirement of the Act or Rules

heading.title: Any requirement of the Act or Rules

p.text: The present section only applies where a failure to comply with provisions of the Act or Rules give rise to a specific identifiable irregularity. It does not apply to a party’s asserted failure to comply with general obligations — such as those imposed by CPA s 56(3): Perpetual Trustees Australia Ltd v Heperu Pty Ltd (NoÂ 2) [2009] NSWCA 387; BC200910737Â (plaintiff suing wrong party — successful defendant’s failure to take point — failure to disclose identity of related entity that was the correct defendant — asserted breach of CPA s 56(3) — no basis to set aside final judgment).

level.toc-caption: [s 63.5] Irregularity: final judgments and orders — Supreme Court

heading.title: Irregularity: final judgments and orders — Supreme Court

p.text: It is well settled that an order or decision of a superior court, even one given in excess of its jurisdiction, is at most voidable and remains valid until it is set aside: Scott v Bennett (1871) LR 5 HL 234 at 245; Revell v Blake (1873) LR 8 CP 533 at 544; Cameron v Cole (1944) 68 CLR 571 at 590; [1944] ALR 130Â . Thus, not only ought such an order be obeyed: Russell v East Anglian Railway Co (1850) 3 Mac & G 104; 42 ER 201 at 208; Rubie v Rubie (1911) 13 CLR 350Â ; Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162Â CLR 612; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781Â ; but also any step taken in reliance upon such a decision remains valid even if the decision itself is subsequently set aside, unless, of course, the court can and does make some contrary order: Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 65 ALR 683; (1986) ATPR Â¶40-690Â ; Chief Cmr of Payroll Tax v Group Four Industries Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 680; (1984) 7 ACLR 973Â (creditor bound by a scheme of arrangement); Wilde v Australian Trade Equipment Co Pty Ltd (1981) 145 CLR 590; 34 ALR 148Â (company charge registered pursuant to an order improperly made); Nationwide News Pty Ltd v Samalot Enterprises Pty Ltd (No 2) (1986) 5 NSWLR 227; 10 ACLR 748Â (liquidator entitled to remuneration where winding up order set aside).

Of course, if a judgment has in fact been irregularly obtained then it may be set aside either on appeal or, perhaps, under the court's incidental jurisdiction. For example, it is well established that a defendant who has not been served with the originating process, or one who has not been given notice of the hearing, is entitled to have a judgment against them set aside under the court's incidental jurisdiction: Hoskins v Van Den-Braak (1998) 43 NSWLR 290; BC9801033Â (the defendant is entitled to have any irregular judgment set aside); Craig v Kanssen [1943] 1 KB 256; [1943] 1 All ER 108Â ; White v Weston [1968] 2 QB 647; [1968] 2 All ER 842Â ; Re Pritchard; Ex parte Pritchard v Deacon [1963] Ch 502; [1963] 1 All ER 873Â ; MacFoy v United Africa Co Ltd [1962] AC 152 at 160; [1961] 3 All ER 1169Â ; Re Marsh; Ex parte Marsh v Paramount Leisure Products Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 482; 104 ALR 533Â ; cf Crawford v Fisher (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 102Â ; see further [s 63.12] and [36.15.10] .

level.toc-caption: [s 63.7] Irregularity: final judgments and orders — statutory courts with limited jurisdiction

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 63.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 5(2).

heading.title: Irregularity: final judgments and orders — statutory courts with limited jurisdiction

p.text: Where a court’s jurisdiction is limited, for example by subject matter, amount, or both (such as the District Court or the Local Court) it will ordinarily have power to determine whether or not the proceedings are within its jurisdiction: see Berowra Holdings Pty Ltd v Gordon (2006) 225 CLR 364; 228 ALR 387; [2006] HCA 32; BC200604256 at [16]Â citing Re Macks; Ex p Saint (2000) 204 CLR 158; 176 ALR 545; [2000] HCA 62; BC200007445Â . Similarly, the fact that the particular proceedings are beyond the court’s jurisdictional may provide a proper basis to exercise a power to transfer the proceedings to another court: KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village vÂ Chilcott (2001) 51 NSWLR 516 atÂ 522–524; [2001] NSWCA 116; BC200102124Â . And conduct that occurs in the course of the proceedings will attract the same immunities that would ordinarily apply to proceedings actually within the court’s substantive jurisdiction: Rawlinson vÂ Oliver [1995] 3 NZLR 62Â . At least to that extent, the proceedings themselves may be regarded as having been validly commenced. However if the court proceeds to make a substantive order in the erroneous exercise of that jurisdiction, the order may itself be regarded as a nullity. For example, in Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 445; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072Â , an order of the District Court was held beyond power and incapable of founding proceedings for contempt. Nothing in the present section operates to enlarge the substantive jurisdiction of the statutory courts to which the CPA applies — not only because the present section is expressed to apply only to non-compliance with “this Act and the rules”, but also because of the specific provision in CPA s 5(2) .

level.toc-caption: [s 63.10] Irregularity: commencement or continuation of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 63.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 63(3).

heading.title: Irregularity: commencement or continuation of proceedings

p.text: Under CPA sÂ 63(3) the court has a wide discretion to determine the consequences that will attach to a failure to comply with procedural requirements of the Act or Rules. In this way “mere technicality, any slip, any mistaken step” are prevented from becoming automatically determinative of the result of the proceedings: Harkness v Bell's Asbestos and Engineering Ltd [1967] 2 QB 729 at 736; [1966] 3 All ER 843Â . The discretion applies where there is non-compliance in any respect. Therefore, there is no longer any valid distinction to be made between mere irregularities on the one hand and, on the other, matters which would have been regarded as nullities under the older authorities: Australian Coastal Shipping Commission v Curtis Cruising Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 734Â ; Bank of America National Trust and Savings Assn v Christmas (The Kyriaki) [1993] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 137; (serving of defective writs was “purporting to begin” proceedings). Accordingly, a defective originating process is capable of constituting the “commencement” of proceedings for the purpose of compliance with a relevant limitation period: Hill v Luton Corp [1951] 2 KB 387Â ; Mitchell v Harris Engineering Co Ltd [1967] 2 QB 703Â ; cf Re Pritchard; Ex parte Pritchard v Deacon [1963] Ch 502; [1963] 1 All ER 873Â .

level.toc-caption: [s 63.12] Setting aside judgments and orders because of irregularity

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 63.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.2(4).

heading.title: Setting aside judgments and orders because of irregularity

p.text: The appropriateness of exercising the power to set aside in any individual case will depend upon the relevant circumstances and in particular upon whether the irregularity can be remedied without injustice to the opposing party. A failure to comply with the required form of originating process will generally be remediable by appropriate directions and will be inherently unlikely to have caused prejudice to the defendant: Brady v Barrow Steel Works Ltd [1965] 2 QB 182Â (failure to identify the appropriate division of the court on the originating process). On the other hand, a default judgment irregularly entered without the defendant having been served with the originating process is liable to set aside as a matter of course: Hoskins v Van Den-Braak (1998) 43 NSWLR 290; BC9801033Â (judgment set aside despite the judgment creditor having made an application to pay by instalments). Craig v Kanssen [1943] 1 KB 256; [1943] 1 All ER 108Â ; White v Weston [1968] 2 QB 647; [1968] 2 All ER 842Â ; Re Pritchard; Ex parte Pritchard v Deacon [1963] Ch 502; [1963] 1 All ER 873Â ; MacFoy v United Africa Co Ltd [1962] AC 152 at 160; [1961] 3 All ER 1169Â ; Re Marsh; Ex parte Marsh v Paramount Leisure Products Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 482; 104 ALR 533Â ; cf Crawford v Fisher (1907) 24 WN (NSW) 102Â .

Between these two extremes, the nature of the discretionary power commonly results in permitting the proceedings to continue despite the irregularity: see further [36.15.10] (dealing with substantial irregularities) and [36.15.15] (dealing with incidental irregularity). By way of example courts have refused to exercise the power to set aside proceedings in the following instances:

where the proceedings were commenced pursuant to a registrar's grant of leave even though the registrar acted beyond power: Harkness v Bell's Asbestos and Engineering Ltd [1967] 2 QB 729; [1966] 3 All ER 843Â ; cf Re Pritchard; Ex parte Pritchard v Deacon [1963] Ch 502; [1963] 1 All ER 873Â ;

where an amended pleading was neither filed nor served (although the amendment had been ordered) within the limitation period: Australian Coastal Shipping Commission v Curtis Cruising Pty Ltd (1989) 17 NSWLR 734Â ; cf Fernance v Nominal Defendant (1989) 17 NSWLR 710Â (where it was held that the section could not be relied upon to cure a plaintiff's failure to exercise leave to amend within the limitation period);

where a defendant’s offer of compromise was accepted despite the fact that the plaintiff had not complied with a statutory pre-condition before commencing the proceedings: Berowra Holdings Pty Ltd v Gordon (2006) 225 CLR 364; 228 ALR 387; [2006] HCA 32; BC200604256Â .

level.toc-caption: [s 63.15] Within a reasonable time and before taking a fresh step

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 63.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 sÂ 63(4).

heading.title: Within a reasonable time and before taking a fresh step

p.text: CPA sÂ 63(4) makes it clear that these two requirements are cumulative. A failure to object promptly to an irregularity may prevent a party from taking the point later: Reynolds v Coleman (1887) 36 ChÂ D 453 (one year delay); Pontin v Wood [1962] 1Â QB 594 (four months delay): even if the defendant does not take any step in the proceedings: Charles P Kinnell & Co Ltd v Harding Wace & Co [1918] 1Â KB 405 (corporate plaintiff acting without solicitor — no objection by defendant until after default judgment obtained).

Where parties take a fresh step in the proceedings after they have acquired knowledge of an irregularity, the taking of that step may prevent them from taking the point thereafter: Brennan v Brennan (1953) 89 CLR 129; [1953] ALR 528; (1953) 27 ALJR 120; BC5300600Â ; Wentworth v Rogers (NoÂ 3) (1986) 6 NSWLR 642Â . Whether it will appears to depend upon the nature of the step taken and whether it is properly to be regarded as one which is only consistent with treating the other party's actions as valid and regular: Rein v Stein (1892) 66 LT 469 at 471Â . This will occur, eg, if the step taken goes beyond what is reasonably necessary to raise the objection and make out a case to support it. Thus, the entry of an unconditional appearance (Re Chittenden [1970] 3 All ER 562; [1970] 1 WLR 1618Â ) or an application for an order directing the plaintiff to serve a statement of claim (Fry v Moore (1889) 23 QBD 395; [1886-90] All ER Rep 309Â ; Boyle v Sacker (1888) 39 Ch D 249Â ) or acquiescence in the making such an order (Richardson v Le Maitre [1903] 2 Ch 222Â ) waives any irregularity relating to the service of the originating process. Similar actions of waiver include: making an application for discovery (Russell v McLeod (1897) 23 VLR 543; 4 ALR 23Â ) making an application for security for costs (The Assunta [1902] P 150Â ; see also White v Hardwick (1922) 23 SR (NSW) 6; 39 WN (NSW) 249Â ); making an offer of compromise (Gordon v Berowra Holdings Pty Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 427; [2005] NSWCA 27; BC200501077Â ); certifying readiness for trial (Orbell v Bundaleer Lodge Nursing Home Pty Ltd [1988] 1 Qd R 152 at 154Â ); applying for an adjournment of the hearing (Kingstone Tyre Agency Pty Ltd v Blackmore [1970] VR 625Â ) or participating at the hearing on questions relating to the merits of the plaintiff's claim: McM v C (NoÂ 2) [1980] 1 NSWLR 27 at 40Â .

However, the test as to what is reasonably necessary may not always be easy to apply. Conduct which amounts to a submission to the jurisdiction of the court for some purposes will not necessarily prevent reliance upon an irregularity: Rein v Stein (1892) 66 LT 469Â (inspect documents annexed to affidavits — no waiver); Wood v Middleton [1897] 1 Ch 151Â (answering interrogatories — no waiver); Williams v Society of Lloyd's [1994] 1 VR 274 at 292–4Â (application for particulars of statement of claim pending hearing of summons to set aside service — no waiver); Schweitzer v Kroner Verwaltungs GmbH (SC(Vic), Chernov J, NoÂ 10444/93, 24 June 1997, unreported, BC9703270) (application to dismiss proceeding for want of prosecution pending hearing of objection of want of jurisdiction — no waiver). Thus the entry of a conditional appearance may not prevent a party from seeking to have the proceedings set aside for irregularity: Leal v Dunlop Bio-processes International Ltd [1984] 1 WLR 874Â ); Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310 at 335; 32 ALJR 7Â ); even though, if the application to set aside is unsuccessful, the conditional appearance will be regarded as a voluntary submission to the court's jurisdiction: Henry v Geoprosco International Ltd [1976] QB 726Â (following Harris v Taylor [1915] 2 KB 580Â and not following Re Dulles Settlement [1951] Ch 842Â ). In Hoskins v Van Den-Braak (1998) 43 NSWLR 290; BC9801033Â , default judgment was set aside where the originating process had not been served, despite the fact that the defendant made an application to pay by instalments.
